Current commit [cbd8dbb499](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/cbd8dbb49900100eee51adbf5466ee66097e3f36)
Reference commit [a52aa033a1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/a52aa033a18f691fabbec4a1787cce8fee0da54f)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Closes #18942.

maintainer merge

```suggestion
-- The left hand side is not in simp normal form, see the variant below.
```
?

What's going on here? These seem like a reasonable simp lemma unless I'm missing something.

(On an adjacent note, does this lemma actually require both types to be in the same universe?)
(yes, because it's a category theoretic statement)

It's not currently a simp lemma, and it has not been for a year, and everything has been fine. 

Adding `@[simp]` is definitely out of scope for this PR, although I would encourage people noticing `simp`s they would like to add to the library to do so in separate PRs.
Same here.
This to me seems like a better `simp` lemma than the one tagged above, which is the reason this doesn't work. Is it too much of a breaking change to just swap the attributes?
I don't see what you mean. The lemma above talks about any element of the conditionally complete field, rather than just a rational number
The first lemma just gets rid of this predicate always. Whereas this lemma is able to simplify further in a special case.
Please continue this in a separate PR, thanks.
This also seems like a good `simp` lemma, is it being duplicated elsewhere?
Irrelevant now?
All of these are valid dsimp lemmas (sorry, can't change myself because I am commuting)
Reverted.
Looks like a vamlid dsimp lemma
Reverted

```suggestion
```

nodes.title: `@[simps]` is sometimes used to generate lemmas that we don't want `@[simp]` on
